We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely experiencing angioedema as a side effect of his new hypertension medication. Among the options, decreased bradykinin degradation is the most likely mechanism. Bradykinin is a vasodilator and increased levels can cause increased permeability of blood vessels, leading to edema. In normal circumstances, bradykinin is rapidly degraded by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), but some hypertension medications can inhibit ACE, leading to increased levels of bradykinin and triggering angioedema.
